items.title: Record DDoS Hits 7.3Tbps with Massive UDP Flood
items.summary: - A **record-breaking DDoS attack** reached an unprecedented **7.3 terabits per second** of junk traffic, overwhelming a Cloudflare customer site. - The attack used a **UDP flood** targeting over 34,500 ports, sending traffic equivalent to over 9,300 HD movies in 45 seconds. - This exploit took advantage of UDP’s connectionless nature to bombard the server, crippling its ability to handle legitimate traffic.

items.title: Israel-Linked Predatory Sparrow Hackers Target Iran's Financial System with Devastating Cyberattacks
items.author: Wired.com
items.summary: The Israel-linked hacker group Predatory Sparrow has launched destructive cyberattacks on Iran's financial sector, destroying over $90 million in crypto assets and crippling bank systems tied to the regime. These politically motivated attacks disrupt Iran’s economy and highlight escalating cyber warfare’s serious consequences.

items.title: Scammers Inject Fake Support Numbers into Legitimate Websites via Google Ads
items.author: Maggie Jauregui
items.summary: Tech support scammers exploit Google ads by injecting fake phone numbers into official websites, misleading users into calling fraudulent support lines. This technique threatens vulnerable users by facilitating financial and privacy scams, highlighting the need for cautious ad clicking and improved site security.

items.title: Preserving Human Creativity: Archiving Pre-AI Content Like Pre-Nuclear Steel
items.author: Graham-Cumming
items.summary: Graham-Cumming’s project archives human-created content from before the AI boom, preserving a snapshot of authentic pre-AI creativity. This effort parallels past preservation of uncontaminated materials like low-background steel, highlighting the importance of safeguarding pure human expression from AI influence for future historical verification.

items.title: Cybersecurity takes a big hit in new Trump executive order
OpenAI weighs “nuclear option” of antitrust complaint against Microsoft
Vandals Cut Fiber-Optic Lines Disrupting Spectrum Internet Service
items.summary: Recent vandalism involving the cutting of fiber-optic lines has caused significant internet outages for Spectrum subscribers. This highlights ongoing challenges in infrastructure security amidst rising copper theft, prompting Spectrum to offer rewards and collaborate with law enforcement. The incident underscores the vulnerability and need for protective measures in critical internet networks.

items.title: Apple Introduces Secure Passkey Import and Export for Enhanced Interoperability
items.summary: Apple unveils a secure, user-initiated method to import and export passkeys directly between apps using Face ID authentication, enhancing security and interoperability. This new approach eliminates risks tied to traditional credential export files, advancing passkey usability and adoption. It marks significant progress against password vulnerabilities and phishing.

items.title: Disney and Universal Sue Midjourney Over AI Image Copyright Infringement
items.summary: Disney and NBCUniversal have filed a landmark lawsuit against AI image generator Midjourney, accusing it of copyright infringement by reproducing characters without permission. The studios highlight Midjourney's refusal to implement protective measures despite repeated requests, marking a significant legal battle in AI ethics and intellectual property. This case illustrates growing tensions between Hollywood and AI firms over creative rights.

items.title: OpenAI’s o3-pro Launch Challenges AI 'Reasoning' Definitions and Advances Capabilities
items.author: Benj Edwards
items.summary: OpenAI's new o3-pro model offers improved simulated reasoning for complex tasks like math and coding at a fraction of previous costs, yet studies reveal its 'reasoning' is pattern matching, not true logic. Understanding these limits is crucial as AI evolves toward general intelligence and practical application.

items.title: Two Secure Boot Exploits Found in the Wild; Microsoft Patches Only One
items.author: Dan Goodin
items.summary: Researchers uncovered two Secure Boot exploits that bypass device protections, with Microsoft patching only one. This reveals vulnerabilities in firmware authentication affecting many devices, highlighting risks despite Secure Boot’s intended security. Understanding these exploits is crucial for device security and the ongoing challenge of firmware protection.

items.title: OpenAI Partners with Google Cloud Amidst Intense AI Competition
items.summary: OpenAI has surprised the AI industry by signing a deal to use Google Cloud's computing infrastructure, diversifying beyond Microsoft Azure. This alliance highlights how competitors collaborate to meet soaring AI demands, with OpenAI leveraging Google's resources to support rapid growth and AI development.

items.title: Meta Invests Billions in AI Superintelligence Amid Industry Rivalry
items.author: Sam Machkovech
items.summary: Meta is creating a new AI research lab led by Alexandr Wang to pursue superintelligence, a type of AI surpassing human cognitive abilities, despite ongoing conceptual uncertainties. This move signals Meta's commitment to compete fiercely in AI development, reflecting broader industry ambitions to achieve advanced AI breakthroughs.

items.title: FAA to Replace Windows 95 and Floppy Disk Technology in U.S. Air Traffic Control Systems
items.summary: The FAA plans to modernize its air traffic control systems, currently reliant on Windows 95 and floppy disks, by initiating a major infrastructure overhaul. This upgrade addresses safety and sustainability concerns, marking a critical step for aviation technology relevant to millions of travelers nationwide.

items.title: Anthropic Launches Custom AI Chatbot for US National Security Operations
items.summary: Anthropic has unveiled Claude Gov, a custom AI chatbot tailored for US national security agencies to aid in classified intelligence work and strategic planning. These models are designed to handle sensitive information with enhanced language skills and operate within secure environments, highlighting AI's growing role in defense. This development underscores the increasing adoption of specialized AI tools in government sectors.

items.title: Millions of Low-Cost Android Devices Infected with Malware Turning Home Networks into Crime Platforms
items.summary: Millions of inexpensive Android devices are infected with the BadBox malware, derived from the advanced Triada Trojan, turning consumer networks into platforms for illicit activities. Despite Google's efforts to block it, these pre-infected devices enable crimes like advertising fraud and proxy services, posing ongoing threats worldwide.

items.title: Anthropic CEO Opposes 10-Year Moratorium on State AI Regulations
items.author: Dario Amodei
items.summary: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei argues against a proposed 10-year freeze on state AI laws, warning that AI’s rapid advancement requires more flexible regulation. He advocates for federal transparency standards over moratoriums to balance innovation with safety, highlighting AI’s transformative potential and economic impact.

items.title: Chrome Removes Trust from Two Certificate Authorities Over Security Concerns
items.summary: Google's Chrome browser has stopped trusting certificates from Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom and Hungary's Netlock due to persistent compliance failures and lack of improvement, highlighting the critical need for reliable digital certificate authorities in web security. This decision underscores significant risks in internet trust infrastructure.

items.title: Meta and Yandex Exploit Android Browsers to De-Anonymize Users
items.summary: Meta and Yandex have been exploiting Android browsers to link users' web browsing identifiers to their app identities, bypassing privacy protections and enabling extensive tracking. This discovery uncovers a covert method that threatens user anonymity and privacy on millions of websites, underscoring urgent security concerns for Android users.

items.title: Broadcom Eliminates Lowest-Tier VMware Partners to Focus on Larger Customers
items.summary: Broadcom has removed the lowest tier from its VMware partner program to concentrate on customers with larger deployments. This move, justified by Broadcom as targeting inactive partners, risks pushing long-time resellers like Members IT Group to seek alternatives, highlighting tensions in partner relations post-acquisition.

items.title: German Law Enforcement Identifies Ransomware Kingpin 'Stern' as Vitaly Nikolaevich Kovalev
items.author: WIRED
items.summary: German police have identified Vitaly Nikolaevich Kovalev as 'Stern,' the elusive leader of the notorious Trickbot ransomware group responsible for global cyberattacks. This breakthrough bridges crucial knowledge gaps in international cybercrime investigations and highlights the ongoing challenge of mitigating sophisticated ransomware threats.

items.title: Google's Veo 3 AI Video Generator Advances Realism with Audio Integration
items.summary: Google's Veo 3 AI model marks a significant leap in video synthesis by generating 8-second high-definition videos with synchronized audio, blurring lines between real and AI-generated media. Its integration of video, audio, and language models pushes creative potential while raising concerns about authenticity and misuse. This breakthrough reshapes digital content creation and verification.

items.title: Stealthy Backdoors Exploit Thousands of Asus Routers via Multiple Vulnerabilities
items.summary: A sophisticated threat actor, likely nation-state linked, has compromised up to 9,500 Asus routers by exploiting multiple vulnerabilities, including a command-injection flaw. Users must check SSH settings for suspicious access and update firmware to remove persistent backdoors, highlighting critical router security risks.

items.title: Inside a Major IT Asset Disposition Site Recycling Hyperscale Hardware
items.summary: This article explores SK TES's large IT asset disposition facility where corporate hardware is carefully inspected, wiped, rated, and prepared for resale or recycling. The process uncovers hidden storage devices and uses innovative methods like full-body laptop skins to improve resale value, showcasing effective IT hardware reuse practices with environmental and economic benefits.

items.title: US Charges 16 Russians Over DanaBot Botnet Involved in Cyberattacks and Espionage
items.summary: The US Department of Justice charged 16 Russians linked to DanaBot, a malware operation that infected over 300,000 devices globally, facilitating ransomware, wartime cyberattacks, and espionage. This case highlights the blurred lines between cybercrime and state espionage, emphasizing its broad impact and financial losses.

items.title: Researchers Reveal How GitLab’s AI Developer Assistant Can Be Exploited to Insert Malicious Code
items.summary: Researchers demonstrated that GitLab's AI assistant Duo can be tricked via prompt injection to insert malicious code and leak sensitive data, highlighting significant security risks in AI-driven developer tools. This insight underscores the need for caution and improved safeguards when integrating AI into software workflows.

items.title: Google’s Veo 3 AI Model Advances Video Synthesis with Audio but Shows Quirky Glitches
items.summary: Google’s new Veo 3 AI model integrates synchronized audio into video synthesis, a first for the industry, enabling realistic eight-second clips with voices and sound effects. However, quirks remain, such as unusual crunchy spaghetti-eating sounds, highlighting ongoing challenges in AI training data representation. This marks a significant leap in generative video AI's realism and potential uses.
